PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Plant Variety Rights
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection, storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving `property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects, namely:
(i) a slowing down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm.
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes.
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices.
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals.
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination Against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the president and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That whereas the Commonwealth of Australia ratified the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women in 1983, the Government of Victoria in passing the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 is in breach of Article 6 of the Convention which says that `States Parties shall take all appropriate measures, including legislation, to supress all forms of traffic in women and exploiting of prostitution of women'.
That the Victorian Planning (Brothels) Act 1984 provides legal authority to brothel operators to traffic in and exploit the prostitution of women and to live off the earnings of prostitutes.

That whereas the Federal Minister for Health has counselled citizens to shun promiscuity (The Australian 26/1/85) because of the serious and sometimes fatal health hazards, the operations of legalised brothels encourages promiscuity and the spread of diseases, including AIDS.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Government of Australia having ratified the UN Convention on Women remain consistent in its obligations to uphold the Articles of the Convention and request the Victorian Government to immediately repeal the Planning (Brothels) Act 1984.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth.

1. That the present Federal tax system is not equitable, readily understandable or manageable. It is making a material contribution to the decline in ethical standards in Australia, and in the opinion of many eminent Australians it is a tax system that basically makes us into a nation of cheats.

2. Some classes of taxpayers are more heavily taxed than others and two groups, wage and salary earners and small businesses, through the impact of inflation on the progressive rate structure, have suffered disproportionately in recent years.
3. A great many people see cheating the tax system as a necessary response to what they regard as cheating by Governments.

4. Through excessive marginal income tax rates, the spirit of free enterprise and hard work is being stifled. The groups in the community who generate savings are being discouraged from investing those savings in capital for business.

5. Any reform of the taxation system needs to be comprehensive and not piecemeal. Further, it requires an unimpeachable commitment from all political parties and parliamentarians to adopt a totally bi-partisan approach in debating tax reform proposals and legislation.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Federal Government will use the forthcoming Taxation Summit meeting as the occasion to announce the formation of one or more working parties committed to the development of a taxation system that will ensure that the necessary Government revenue is raised in the most equitable and efficient manner possible and that such working party (parties) be provided with adequate resources so as to permit the tabling of their recommendations in the Parliament not later than 30 June 1986.

Further, your petitioners believe that one of the most significant ways this country could celebrate its Bi-Centenary is through the introduction, by 1988, of legislation that will give the people a fair and equitable taxing system.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth.
Introduction of any additional capital gains taxes, wealth taxes or death duties is opposed on the grounds that:
they adversely affect the small and medium size businesses in Australia, destroying incentive and discouraging investment in this important area of the economy;
the Australian economy, and employment in particular, is heavily reliant on growth in small businesses;

any capital gains that might result when owners of small businesses finally sell the business are not `windfall gains' but the result of many hard years of work and sacrifice, with very little being taken out of the business by way of salaries so that the maximum amount of money can be ploughed back into the business to create growth and jobs;
the owners of small businesses often depend on a capital gain-which are simply deferred salaries-when they eventually sell their business to sustain them in retirement;
Your Petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, will protect the rights of private enterprise and reject any inequitable additional taxes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The petition of certain undersigned citizens of Australia shows that the proposed private member's Bill introduced by Senator Harradine-An Act to Prohibit Experiments Involving The Use of Human Embryos Created by In Vitro Fertilisation-disadvantages infertile members of the community seeking treatment through the current medical procedure known as in vitro fertilisation because the inadequate definition of terminology relating to the proposals in the said Bill will prevent any further development and improvement in the relevant medical research anywhere in Australia and, hence, lead to the cessation of the freeze/thaw technique currently associated with the preservation of excess embryos created and intended specifically for the purpose of later implantation into the uterus of an infertile woman seeking treatment. We strongly believe that research should be allowed to continue under the strict guidelines already laid down by the National Health and Medical Research Council and Victoria's ``Infertility (Medical Procedures) Act 1984''.

Since the proposed Bill infringes on the personal rights and liberties of infertile couples to have children, your petitioners as in duty bound therefore humbly pray that the Senate will view with sympathy our opposition to the afore-mentioned Bill and not support its passage through the Senate.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Home Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of South Australia respectfully showeth that:

Without any warning and at the worst possible moment, the Federal Government has abandoned the pensioner patients in South Australia's Nursing Homes. These people are suffering undeserving hardship and trauma as a result of the Federal Government's decision to freeze the nursing home benefit levels in South Australia.

The pensioner patients and those on fixed incomes now cannot expect any relief from recent significant fee increases approved by the Department of Community Services and which have coincided with the decision to freeze benefits.

80-85 per cent of nursing home patients are pensioners and the majority are now required to pay in excess of their pension for their nursing care for the very first time. Some are paying over $5 per day on top of their pension. Many are looking for cheaper nursing care that doesn't exist.
We request that the Federal Government:

1. alleviate the distress of South Australia's nursing home patients and their families by effective restoration of the principle that pensioner patients should not have to pay more than their pension for nursing home care
2. restore the review of the benefit rates in November 1985
3. resolve its concerns over health care costs with the South Australian Government rather than inflicting unnecessary suffering on nursing home patients.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: TREATY ON THE NON-PROLIFERATION OF NUCLEAR WEAPONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) calls upon the Government to seriously and openly, with public consultation, address the questions raised by the Nuclear Non-proliferation Treaty Review Conference to be held in Geneva beginning at the end of August, with a view to
(i) submitting to the Review Conference a practical multilateral disarmament program;
(ii) supporting all moves to impose a timetable for superpower disarmament; and
(iii) to either propose or support other nations' proposals that the Review Conference resolve to urge immediate conclusion by the superpowers of a comprehensive test ban treaty; and

(ii) sponsor a non-government organisation representative to attend the conference; and
(iii) finance meetings of non-government organisations involved in peace and disarmament, to brief them on the Review and discuss the future of the NPT.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON PRIVATE HOSPITALS AND NURSING HOMES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a statement concerning the Government's response to the report from the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes entitled `Private Nursing Homes in Australia: Their Conduct, Administration and Ownership'.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the text of the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I wish to make a statement concerning the Government's response to the report from the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes entitled `Private Nursing Homes in Australia: Their Conduct, Administration and Ownership'. The report was presented to the President of the Senate in November 1984, by the chairperson of the Committee, Senator Giles, and tabled on 21 February 1985.

Before proceeding, I should like to express the Government's appreciation of the Committee's work. In doing so I wish to acknowledge the extent of the Committee's activities since it was initially appointed in September 1981. In the course of its deliberations it considered 161 written submissions relating to private hospitals and nursing homes, visited a cross section of nursing homes, conducted a survey of ownership and heard evidence from a large number of witnesses.

The report gives an interesting historical perspective on how the Commonwealth's programs in the nursing homes area have evolved and addresses the important issues relating to nursing home care. It addresses questions of fundamental significance in the care of the frail aged and younger disabled.

This Government is committed to improving the provision of services for the frail aged and the younger disabled. One of its strategies for achieving this is to redress the imbalance between nursing home care and hostel and community care. It seeks to do this by restraining growth in nursing homes and encouraging the expanded provision of a range of hostel and community care. At the same time it is committed to continue support for nursing homes for those who need that care.

The Government has already taken a number of significant initiatives in the aged care area that will impact directly or indirectly on nursing homes. In the 1984/85 Budget the Government announced the home and community care program, a major initiative to encourage the development of community care services for the aged and younger disabled. Through this program the Government is seeking to enable aged people to receive the services most appropriate to their needs. It is anticipated that as community care services are expanded there will be less pressure for the inappropriate placement of aged people in nursing homes. The Government has also been active in providing financial support for the development and evaluation of geriatric assessment.

During December 1984, the Department of Community Services was established facilitating the co-ordinated development of aged care policies at the Commonwealth level and enabling the administration of all aspects of the Commonwealth's nursing home advantages to be integrated.

The Government recognises that there is an urgent need to tackle the many complex issues in the nursing homes area and the matters discussed and the recommendations in the committee's report provide a focus for future government action. The Government has commissioned studies on nursing home and hostel care, including consultancies on costs of nursing homes and staffing and quality of care in nursing homes. The results of some of the consultancies will not be available until at least the end of this calendar year.

In the meantime, intensive study is proceeding in the key areas which the Committee has addressed. For example, it is planned to develop over the next few months a detailed picture of assessment mechanisms currently in place and their effectiveness. Analysis of the various alternative ways of introducing a program grant approach is proceeding. The questions raised by the Committee involving information on nursing home ownership are being explored. Mechanisms for achieving simple and effective avenues for redress for persons in nursing homes and hostels are being considered. The best ways to upgrade procedures used to inspect standards of care in nursing homes are being investigated and the Government recognises the importance of ensuring that sub-standard care is eliminated. The ways in which residents and the community may be provided with structured opportunities to contribute to the quality of life in nursing homes are also being examined.

The Senate will appreciate that these are extremely complex and inter-related issues and it would be, in the Government's view, unproductive to seek to respond in detail at this stage to the Committee's specific recommendations.

Moreover, the Government confidently expects that many of the issues brought to light by the Committee's further report on private hospitals will need to be considered in an integrated fashion with the recommendations in this first report on nursing homes. Therefore, the Government seeks the indulgence of the Senate so that it may defer providing a detailed response to specific recommendations until both reports of the Committee are available, the studies commissioned by the Department are complete and the Government's own forward plan in this field has been settled.
The Government's objective will be to provide such a detailed response in the autumn sitting next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. Continually we see the Government failing to take action on issues such as this and merely putting off the evil day until it has been through its so-called reviews of these various matters. One of the worst examples of the Government's procrastination in this area is right before us in this very case.

The emphasis that the Government has put upon the development of the home and community care program has been exposed as a fraud since it was first announced in the Budget of 1984. This continued reiteration by the Government as the solution to every problem in the area of aged and frail aged care is an absolute nonsense. There has been no commitment of resources of any great value to that area and, consequently, we cannot see that as the long term solution to the problem. I believe that this Government has failed desperately to show its concern for the frail aged. I am very concerned that the Government has headed right down the wrong direction in this regard as it has with so many other initiatives in the area of the frail aged and of the aged generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Along with unemployment, the major problem facing Australia today is our inability to live within our means internationally. Over the last 5 years we have run balance of payments deficits, and now 30% of our exports go to servicing debt payments on money we have borrowed to balance our trade deficit.

The best and quickest way to overcome this problem is to concentrate on making our industries internationally competitive. There is no reason why Australian industry cannot be as efficient as the best of Japanese industry. If the Japanese can apply management techniques to develop industries as efficient as any in the world, why cannot Australia?

It has long been popular to consider the Japanese as a race apart. But the Japanese are human beings like us, with the same human emotions. We should adapt the same management techniques that have proven to be so successful in Japan and then seek to improve on them. In the economic war Australia has not yet sought to fundamentally assess the competition, let alone to beat it.

It can be done. Our aim should be no less than to make the best of our industries the most efficient in the world, and make the world our potential market. We would then solve our unemployment problem and our balance of trade problem with one blow.
In the early 80s American industrialists started to wake up that they were being out gunned by the Japanese. It is surprising they did not wake up earlier.
They used to blame low wages in Japan, but by the early 80s Japanese wages were generally higher than in America and they are generally higher than Australian wages today.

Starting from a pile of rubble after the War and with a reputation for producing shoddy imitations, by 1980 Japan had developed an industrial machine that was the envy of the world. In 1980 the Japanese produced more cars than the American auto industry. By that time Chrysler had gone broke, General Motors and Ford were losing money, and the only thing that saved the American car makers was Japan's willingness to impose voluntary export restrictions.

In 1980, 90% of the world's motor cycles came from Japan, 55% of all steel consumed in America by American industry was produced in Japan. American steel companies were losing money, and again were only saved by voluntary import restrictions.

The Japanese led the world in the production of cameras, machine tools and watches, and were challenging for world leadership in computers, typewriters, sewing machines, industrial robots, micro-processors-the list goes on almost forever.

What is the secret of Japanese success? They have a different approach to the management of their companies. They have embraced wholeheartedly for many years now the principle of participatory management. They have developed organisational structures that provide for the total involvement of all employees, and an ability to take notice of the individual.

In 1982, with the backing of the then Shadow Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Bob Hawke, and the tacit acquiescence of the ACTU, I succeeded in getting an Industrial Democracy Bill passed by the Senate. It was the first time the Australian Parliament had ever debated industrial democracy. If it hadn't been for the double dissolution I think this Bill would have passed the Lower House, because both Mr Fraser and Mr Macphee were prepared to support it.

As a practising industrialist and one who has led for some 30 years an industry that has attempted to embrace principles of employee participation, I now introduce a re-vamped Industrial Democracy Bill which takes account of continuing and up-to-the-minute experience in this area.

The Bill contains five criteria which define what is meant by industrial democracy. An enterprise that can convince a 7-member Industrial Democracy Board that it has substantially complied with at least 4 of the 5 criteria will be eligible to apply for a Government incentive in the form of an 8% reduction in company tax. The five criteria are:
1. At least 8 per cent employee share holding to give employees a stake in the enterprise in which they work.

2. A cellular organisation with autonomous working groups based on performance centres throughout the enterprise. This is important because such groups have the ability to meet change quickly, and to engender innovation.
3. A profit sharing scheme to reward people for their efforts and to ensure open communication on such things as sales performance and profits.
4. A consultative council to discuss small internal problems before they become major matters requiring the attention of trade unions, and

5. Small group activity. This is a very important provision of the Bill and requires that an enterprise establish small groups of about 10 people throughout the entire organisation. These groups are to be led by carefully selected and trained group leaders and are required to discuss, during working hours, such things as quality, efficiency, innovation and new equipment and to make recommendations on these to management.
The question may well be asked-if industrial democracy is so good for business, then why does it not adopt it anyway, without Government assistance?

The first answer is that most Australians, including Australian executives have only a very hazy idea about what is meant by industrial democracy. It means different things to different people, and like motherhood is generally perceived to be a good thing. Australians have talked about industrial democracy for many years, but very few companies have applied even its rudimentary principles. This is because there is an ingrained conservatism in Australian management along the lines that workers are there to do what they're told, and amongst workers that they are not employed to tell the boss how to do his job. It needs a Government initiative to break down these ingrained attitudes in Australia.

Once the change of attitude gets under way, and people see that companies applying the principles set out in this Bill are successful, and once the Industrial Democracy Board starts disseminating through our tertiary institutions information on how to successfully apply the principles, then industrial democracy in Australia will become self-perpetuating and the Government, if it wishes, could progressively withdraw from the scene,
This Bill requires the Government to make $20m available each year for the first five years, and then to reassess the situation.

If Australia is to overcome its critical balance of trade problem, it must turn to the manufacturing sector to improve its export performance. Our industries can be, and should be, as efficient as any in the world. If the Government co-operates, we can do it,

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to be subjected to attempts to suspend Standing Orders every time an honourable senator feels that the business paper should be rearranged to meet his whim, the business of the Senate will be put aside while we debate procedural matters. We have five or six of them now, and any honourable senator who thinks that proper time ought to be set aside for discussion of a matter has only to discuss it with the Manager of Government Business, Senator Grimes, to find that that will be accommodated. As far as I am aware, no attempt was made to do so on this occasion and therefore I suggest that the Senate should not support the suspension of Standing Orders moved by Senator Baume.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not support Senator Peter Baume's motion to bring item No. 7 to the top of the list. SPEECH.PARA: If we moved the order of business around every time the community was confused about some matter we would be changing the order of business on an hourly basis. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

Mr Deputy President, I believe that this matter should be raised and debated so that the concern and confusion that exists in the community because of the statements of the Chairman of this Committee can be put to rest.

TALK.START.PARA: -I would like to speak to the motion before the Chair. Primary exports are vitally important to this country and the live sheep export trade is very much part and parcel of our export business. It is an important export income earner.
—On a point of order: I think Senator MacGibbon is dealing with the argument itself and not the question of the suspension of Standing Orders.

—I am sorry that Senator Grimes finds this all so boring, but why is the Government being so pigheaded? I do not understand it. There has been some confusion in the community.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1985NATIONAL PARKS AND WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AMENDMENT BILL 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 May, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes the substance of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1985 and the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Amendment Bill 1985 and will vote accordingly. I indicate at this stage that the Opposition will be moving a second reading amendment to the Bills. That amendment is now being circulated throughout the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills will implement the Government's decision to grant the land in the Uluru National Park, that is, the Ayers Rock and Mount Olga areas to an Aboriginal land trust. The Bills also will enable the implementation of an agreement with the Aboriginal people to lease that area back to the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service to manage that area as a national park. Our opposition to this legislation is not an opposition to the rights of Aboriginal people or to their need for secure land tenure. It should not be seen in those terms. We are opposed to this legislation because it is bad legislation. We oppose these Bills because Ayers Rock, Uluru and the Olgas are national monuments and belong to all Australians. They are part of a national park. There is no reason why the ownership of that national park should be taken from the people of Australia.

When a land claim was made by the Aboriginal people under the provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act for this area the Aboriginal Land Commissioner judged at that time that this area was not available for claim because it was land alienated to the people of Australia. The Liberal Party of Australia, to which I belong, has a very proud record in terms of its stand, its actions and legislative enactments in relation to Aboriginal land rights and Aboriginal land tenure. Our Aboriginal affairs policy released before the last election contained a strong commitment to Aboriginal rights in this area. That part of the policy stated:

The coalition's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander policy is based on a recognition of the affinity most Aboriginal people have with their land. Aboriginal culture is derived from a unique relationship between the people and their land. Virtually all social, political, economic and spiritual relationships within Aboriginal societies have traditionally been based on land.
Our policy continued:

Therefore, Aboriginals choosing to live on their traditional lands, and who retain some or all of their traditional association with the land should, where practicable, be granted secure title to such land to facilitate a continuation of their lifestyle and culture.

That was the election policy of the Liberal and National parties. That is the policy which members of this Opposition accept and within which we operate. It is still within that policy that we find it impossible to support this legislation in any way. As a senator I worked in 1976 to help put the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act in place. I fought and worked within my own side of Parliament to make sure that it was enacted. I would do so again. Of course, knowing now that the Act needs amendment, knowing in light of experience that the Act is not right as it is, I would do it differently.

We recognise, as I recognised when I was Minister, that the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act needs amending today in the light of experience, but that is another question. We worked to get this legislation into place. It was enacted in 1976 by the Fraser Government. Do not tell us that we do not care about land rights. We have a record in this Parliament of having put the Act in place. As Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, I worked to administer that Act. I was responsible for it, and I worked to support land rights where such rights were an appropriate vehicle for improving the position of Aboriginal people.

When I was Minister we had some conflict involving the State of Queensland and tenure of the reserves in Queensland. At that time, in March 1982, I laid down, with the full backing of the Fraser Cabinet, four principles which the then Government saw as fundamental when dealing with issues relating to tenure in Queensland reserves. I will remind the Senate of those four principles. They were that the integrity of the present reserve boundaries be maintained; that there should be security of tenure for occupants and preservation of their rights to use the land; that local communities should play a significant role in the management of the reserve; and, further, that there should be full consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people before any decisions were made. Those were good principles and were the basis on which we could enter negotiations and betray no one. With those principles we could work to secure for Aboriginal people in Queensland on that occasion the kind of tenure that was necessary. The Opposition still adheres to those four principles.

Further, the Senate should remember that it was the coalition when in government during the Fraser years and the Tonkin Liberal Government in South Australia which introduced the most far-reaching land rights legislation this country has seen. It was the Fraser Government which enacted legislation in the Northern Territory, and it was the Tonkin Liberal Government which enacted the Pitjantjatjara land rights legislation in South Australia. When one remembers the high hopes, the good will, the high spirits that greeted both those legislative achievements and compares the reception which greeted the present Government's so-called preferred option-wanted by none, it seems-it is not hard to understand why it has become the `deferred preferred option'.

We know that the present Government's approach to land rights is not wanted by Premier Burke of Western Australia, it is not wanted by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), it is not wanted by the left wing of the Australian Labor Party, it is not wanted by the Aboriginal communities, if we listen to what they say, and national uniform land rights legislation is not wanted by the Opposition. In fact, it is only preferred by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) and a small number of Cabinet colleagues. It has disappointed Aboriginals around Australia. They tell us they are angry, despondent and rebellious because they believe the Hawke Government has let them down in this area. Once again the rhetoric has outrun the performance. Expectations were raised by the Minister, and in this place by Senator Ryan, much higher than the community was willing to satisfy. Now those expectations are not being met and Aboriginal hopes and aspirations have been disappointed.

It is important that our opposition to this legislation be seen against this background. It is a background of commitment over a long time by my Party and by those of us who have been active in this area, by those of us who have had the good fortune to have been Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs-a commitment to a fair go for what is Australia's most disadvantaged group of people. It is a background of a coalition record on granting land rights in the Northern Territory and a Liberal Party record of granting land rights in South Australia. It is also a background of the ALP's failure to live up to the land rights rhetoric and promises that were made to the Aboriginal people. I digress for a moment to say that we have no doubt by almost any measure Aboriginal Australians still represent the most disadvantaged group. Our policies when we were in government remained committed to overcoming that disadvantage. Let there be no doubt about that-we have a record on this issue over a considerable time.

During the Fraser years, during the time the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act was operating, the Land Commissioner was required to hear claims from traditional groups and to hear evidence relating to traditional association and ownership. The Land Commissioner was then required to report and make recommendations to the government of the day. The fact is that the Land Commissioner recommended some Aboriginal claims and he rejected other claims. From the beginning we had in place a process of judicial judgment under which people went before Mr Justice Toohey, who was then the Land Commissioner-it was Sir William Kearney at the end-and argued their case. If on the merits of that argument the Land Commissioner supported them, a recommendation was made to the Government.

As I said, the Land Commissioner approved some claims and rejected others. But that was not the end of the matter. The Minister then had to make a judgment as part of the process laid down in the Act. I remind the Senate that Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs took that responsibility seriously, and they approved some recommendations and did not approve others. I remember as Minister being faced with recommendations concerning the Borroloola claim, and those recommendations involved negotiations with the community before we reached a resolution. Part of that claim recommended the grant of Vanderlin Island to an Aboriginal land trust. As Minister I did not approve that, because the detriment that would have flowed to a particular Aboriginal in my view made such a grant inappropriate. I am saying that there was a process laid down under the Act, and it was that process which reassured most Australians that what was being done could be justified. The present proposal has gone through none of those processes. The Government has by-passed them. The coalition believes that the Uluru claim should not be introduced through the Parliament in this way and we believe that the Government's approach cannot be justified.

First, there has been no judicial assessment of the present proposal; there has been no hearing of this proposal concerning Uluru before the Land Commissioner. There has been no claim in which people have had to prove the merits of this particular case. It has not been assessed, as other land rights claims have been assessed, before an independent judicial figure as laid down in the land rights legislation. It should have been. The Minister and the Government are bypassing all these essential steps which are so necessary for community acceptance of any land claim. No move has been made to prove the entitlement of Aboriginal people to this land. I think that could be done easily enough. No steps have been taken, under the procedures laid down, to prove the entitlement of these Aboriginal people to the Uluru National Park.

The proposal is no good. It is not fair of the Government to proceed in this way. This is a national park. It is alienated Crown land. It belongs to the people of Australia. It is not available for claim. The Commonwealth has already given it away to the people of Australia as a national park. The Government is simply proceeding in the wrong way by moving through the Parliament to declare that this area will be granted to a land trust. I have taken the trouble to look at the report of the then Aboriginal Land Commissioner, Mr Justice Toohey, on the claim that was made. I refer to his report entitled `Uluru (Ayres Rock) National Park and Lake Amadeus/Luritja Land Claim' which was published, I believe, in August 1979. The report was sent to Senator Chaney, the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and to Mr Ellicott, the then Minister for Home Affairs. If we examine this report of the Land Commissioner we find that he was quite clear about the status of the area which is the subject of the Bill before the Senate. On pages 1 and 2 he said.

When the hearing began in Alice Springs on 2 April 1979 I agreed to hear submissions going to the matter of jurisdiction before dealing with the substantive claim. This I did on 2 and 3 April and on 4 April I delivered my decision. I held that the area of the National Park was not unalienated Crown land and so was not available to be claimed within the Act.

Everything that followed in this report from the Aboriginal Land Commissioner was on the basis that the national park area was alienated Crown land and was not available for claim. He went on in paragraph 66 on page 13, in discussing the Ayers Rock estate and the various Aboriginal estates which are involved in the Aboriginal claim, to say:
The heart of this estate is Uluru itself which is within the National Park and so outside the claim area.
Further, the Land Commissioner said in his formal findings:
The land described in the application, save as to the National Park, the leases within the park and the proposed Ulara village, is unalienated Crown land.

He then went on to name a group of people to whom the claim area belongs in terms of the Act. But the area excludes the national park, and that is the important point. It excludes the national park entirely. If the Government wished to proceed to make the national park available it should at least have set up some way in which the judicial processes laid down under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act could be followed. It has not done so. The whole thing smells of some desire to bypass procedures which have worked well enough in the Northern Territory. The Government had no need to go this way. It could have deemed that the land was available for claim and required the Commissioner to hear the case. Why was the Land Commissioner not brought into the whole thing? The Government does not care about proper procedure.

Further, the Parliament is being asked not only to approve the granting of this land to an Aboriginal land trust without going through the procedures which have been laid down but also to deem a social grouping, a certain community-the Mutitjulu community-as being the traditional owners. That is not the way in which the land rights Act has worked. The traditional owners have been determined by carefully laid down procedures argued before the Land Commissioner. We have no way of knowing whether this particular grouping of people is completely or partially the group of traditional owners.

Why is the Government doing this? If it is determined to take from the Australian people a national asset, why is it not at the very least proceeding to establish the traditional owners in the way laid down under the Act? The answer is that it could not care less about the Act. Not only could the Government not care less but also it does not care what it says. On 19 August 1985 the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs wrote to my colleague Mr Roger Shipton, who is the Opposition spokesman on Aboriginal Affairs, in relation to this matter. In that letter he said, inter alia:

You may be interested to know that in his Report on the Uluru (Ayers Rock) National Park and the Lake Amadeus/Luritja land claim the then Aboriginal Land Commissioner, Mr Justice Toohey, identified not less than 160 traditional Aboriginal owners . . .

Of course he did. They were the traditional owners of land somewhere else. There was no establishment of the legal ownership of the area which the Government is taking now, although it was within the area claimed. There could not be, because the Land Commissioner did not hear any claim or evidence about this area. He was determining the owners of the area which was granted, and Mr Holding wants us to accept that kind of nonsense. We believe that this kind of pre-emptive action is likely to do the thing that is most damaging of all to Aboriginal advancement. I speak as someone who is deeply committed-

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, Senator Ryan has been a failure in everything she has taken on. I would say that my time as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was the most productive of my working life. It was a wonderful time in an excellent department. The action which the Government is taking now is likely to produce a backlash in the general community, the kind of backlash which will not be to the long term advantage of the Aboriginal people. I ask the Government sincerely just to think of that, to think of its role in taking this kind of action and of the backlash it may provoke and the long term effects which may not be to the advantage of Aboriginal people. I draw on my experience as a former Minister to say that Aboriginals are not satisfied with the way this is being done, and many communities I have visited and many people I have talked to say that they are not satisfied.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has failed, not least because it has raised tensions between white and Aboriginal Australians as a result of the action which is before the Senate today, and that is a pity for Australia. It is not fair to Aboriginals and it is not good for the Australian community. There is no basis for taking the land from the national park, from the nation. It should remain a national park, a national asset. The Government has not only taken the land from the nation and given it to a community that has not yet proved its traditional ownership before the Land Commissioner but it has then required the people to lease it back. The Australian people have lost the ownership. They have lost it not on the basis of proper procedure. We as an opposition believe that the area should remain the property of the people of Australia. We believe that it should be given to the Northern Territory Government. For that reason I move the following amendment to the second reading motion:
Leave out all words after `That', insert `the Bills be withdrawn and redrafted to provide for-
(a) ownership of the Uluru National Park to be vested in the Northern Territory, subject to:
(i) an agreement ensuring effective Aboriginal involvement in management of the Park, and
(ii) adequate and appropriate portions of the Park being vested by freehold title in Aboriginals for the purposes of living areas;
(b) a right of entry to all persons subject to protection of sacred sites and the Park; and
(c) the Agreement to be entered into between the Director of National Parks and Wildlife and the Land Council not to come into effect until approved by the Parliament.'.

I now turn to say a few words about the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Amendment Bill. This is the complementary Bill to what the Government is proposing to do. The Fraser Government accepted the significance of Ayers Rock and the Uluru area to the Aboriginal community that resides there. It was for that reason that on 24 May 1977, under a Liberal Government, Uluru National Park was proclaimed under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act. This proclamation provided a means to safeguarding access to the wider Australian community, while at the same time ensuring that sacred sites and sites of significance in the area as a whole continue to be protected.

Uluru is the focus of Aboriginal creation beliefs and dreamtime stories. It incorporates Aboriginal lore and inherited knowledge. The park brings together the age-old traditions of the Aboriginal people and the modern perceptions of a young Australia, an Australia with people of many races and creeds, all of whom regard Ayers Rock as a national symbol. Ayers Rock brings a perception of timelessness and continuity together with a sense of stability and pride in the nation. It is truly our country's symbol of solidity and strength. We believe that Ayers Rock should belong and be seen to belong to the people of Australia. The Fraser declaration was appropriate to achieve that purpose and there has been no reason offered in logic to seek this change or to repudiate the formula which we put in place. The Opposition opposes this legislation as well because it seeks to give title to Uluru National Park to one Aboriginal organ- isation which has not been proven to be the traditional owners. We are not sure it is the community of traditional owners. Such action negates the belief held by millions of Australians that the rock belongs to us all.

In the few moments remaining to me, I want to say a few words about the proposed management of the park. I understand that my colleague Senator Puplick will say more about this later. In this situation, it is quite clear that the Government does not trust the local Aboriginal community because it has constructed a management plan in such a way that ultimate authority will rest undoubtedly with the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service. Regardless of the majority decision of the board, we will find that disagreements between the Director and the board which is managing the park will ultimately be decided by the Commonwealth Minister. I say to the Australian Democrats that they will be putting into the hands of a Minister power to override what may be the wishes of a board of directors.

Finally, I want to refer to the wider changes that this legislation seeks to make to the concept of national parks. The schedule of the Bill contains five amendments which will seek to change the way in which national parks are proclaimed. Honourable senators should be aware of these amendments. The first of the five changes is to allow land to be added to an existing park, reserve or wilderness zone by varying an existing proclamation. This amendment provides no role for the Parliament and I am surprised that the Australian Democrats would go along with that. The Bill also seeks to clarify the public comment requirement in regard to the declaration, amendment or revocation of a park, reserve or wilderness zone. It will do so in a way which will exclude Uluru from such consideration because it goes on to say that a special `region' which now includes stages 1 and 2 of Kakadu will now also include Uluru National Park and public comment will not be required for an addition to a park, reserve or wilderness zone within the `region'.

The Government is saying that it can do what it likes to Uluru and there will be no public comment and no role for the Parliament. I remind the Senate that the political wheel turns. The Senate should be very careful because a legitimate role for the Parliament is being given away. Although the Opposition notes these amendments and wonders at them it will not oppose them all. We believe that the Government has just got it wrong. We believe that the Government, if it wants to do justice to the Uluru community, could have proceeded in other ways. It has chosen the one way that heightens the sense of unfairness, of inappropriate pro- cedure and of inadequate and inappropriate practice. We urge the Senate to accept the amendments which the Opposition has laid down and, if these are not acceptable, to oppose the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to remind the Senate of a motion that was passed in 1975. I think it is appropriate that we remind each other-some of us were not here at the time-of the feelings in this chamber in 1975 in respect of Aboriginal and Islander entitlement to recognition. On 19 September 1974 the then Senator Bonner of Queensland, in accordance with a notice of motion he moved on 11 July 1974, moved:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate accepts the fact that the indigenous people of Australia, now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, were in possession of the entire nation prior to the 1788 First Fleet landing at Botany Bay, urges the Australian Government to admit prior ownership by the said indigenous people, and introduce legislation to compensate the people now known as Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders for the dispossession of their land.

That motion was passed unanimously on 20 February 1975. I think it is a very sorry commentary on politics and the politicians in this country that we have now seen the wheel turn a full circle, that the people who advocated and supported that type of philosophy are now coming out with the sort of grandstanding nonsense that we have just heard from Senator Baume. I am sure we will hear the same type of thing from some of his colleagues though, fortunately, not all of them.

I am absolutely confused as to how the Opposition was so able to accommodate the idea of Aboriginal ownership of Kakadu National Park in 1979 yet now by 1985 it has decided that such an arrangement is completely incompatible in respect of Uluru. The attitude taken by the Opposition is fundamental to this debate because it highlights the fact that the Opposition is just using this entire important question as a very opportunistic cynical exercise to mislead the people of Australia. Politicians should be taking a lead on this type of issue.

It is so easy for the average Australian to be misinformed and to get overemotional about Ayers Rock, our national symbol. It is up to the responsible parliamentarians in this place and the other place to set some tone in the debate about something as important as this. But, no, the Opposition, in true political sense, cannot resist the temptation to grandstand. We will hear today from a majority, though not all, of Opposition speakers who will make passionate speeches with mock concern about our heritage. Where were they during the Franklin Dam debate? Were they concerned in those days about our heritage? Were they then concerned about whether Ayers Rock belongs to all Australians or about the way in which Ayers Rock was being taken away from all Australians?

The stand taken by the Opposition has me absolutely mystified. The Opposition has made completely emotive claims which somehow conjure up images of the Federal Government performing magic rites to spirit Ayers Rock away to some secret hiding place. Quite frankly, some of the speeches that I heard in the other place-and it seems as if the tone has been set here for something similar today-would lend themselves to a wonderful send-up by Max Gillies. I can imagine Max Gillies doing a goanna style send-up-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) sitting aloft Ayers Rock as it hovers over the tourist buses and then mysteriously disappears. Really, this issue is far too important to have this cynical nonsense about the Federal Government taking away Ayers Rock from the people of Australia.

First of all, we have to examine the two faces of Paul Everingham on the question of land rights generally and Ayers Rock in particular. Some of the views of the Hon. Paul Everingham were put in a speech to the National Press Club in 1982-I will not quote his entire speech-when he said:
Arguments about who owns Australia are simplistic and destructive.
I wish Opposition senators would remember that warning of Paul Everingham. He continued:
All Australians, black and white, own Australia. The term, Commonwealth of Australia speaks for itself.
Aboriginal land rights in the Northern Territory are a fact of life.
Land ownership has led to a re-emergence of pride and purpose in many Aboriginal communities.
My government's concern is that land rights really work in the Territory community.
Through land ownership Aboriginals will be able to participate in the economy, or decide not to. That will be up to them.
Today, more than two-thirds of Aboriginals in the Territory . . . live on land to which they hold inalienable title or which is under claim.

Our record shows our concern. Twenty-seven per cent of land, including some of the best, within the town of Alice Springs and 325 hectares of prime land in Darwin have been handed over . . . to Aboriginals by the Territory Government.

By arrangement with traditional owners and the Northern Land Council, and by special legislation through the Territory's Legislative Assembly, the Co-bourg Peninsula-the pride of our conservation reserves-was handed over to Aboriginals as freehold and the area preserved as a national park.
A similar arrangement could be made for Uluru, site of Ayers Rock and the Olgas . . .

That was not a speech made by the present Prime Minister of Australia or by Clyde Holding; that was a speech made by Paul Everingham in 1982. Furthermore, at that time, under the Fraser Government, there was a package of amendments in respect of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. The amendments, which were accepted by the previous Government, contained the following proposals:
The Northern Territory Government would enter into negotiations with the Land Councils for the granting of title to National Parks subject to claim.
Such negotiations would include the two unsuccessful land claims over Uluru and Alligator Rivers Stage II areas.
At the National Press Club in 1982 the then Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, the Hon. Paul Everingham, promised:

The Territory Government will give title to Uluru National Park, including Ayers Rock and Mount Olga and make an arrangement whereby it will continue as a National Park administered jointly by the Northern Territory Conservation Commission and traditional owners.

That is why I am totally disgusted with members of the Opposition regarding their handling of this issue. They have done a complete about-turn. Paul Everingham, of all people, has been thoroughly two-faced on this issue. Let us compare that promise with excerpts from a speech he made in 1985. I will not take up too much time reading it. Let us hear the change in tone when, in 1985, as an Opposition member, he decided to appeal to the lowest common denominator in the Australian community, to those racists in the community. He said:

Throughout Australia people are watching the passage of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill and they are angry, justifiably angry, that this Government is about to give away the best known and best loved symbol of our Australian heritage in a tradeoff to its left wing. Ayers Rock does not belong to this Government. It is not the Government's to give away. Ayers Rock belongs to all the people of Australia.
He continued:

If this legislation is passed . . . the hand-over of Australia's best known, best loved, cultural and spiritual symbol to a small group in the community. This Government will be remembered for it. It will be cursed for it.

It is no wonder that members of the Opposition are weeping in the aisles of the House of Representatives. I imagine that the only curse relating to such a speech by Mr Paul Everingham would come from John Stuart Mill. He would be cursing the members of the Liberal Party who could so abandon those very genuine and traditional principles of true liberalism, if indeed there are any people in the Liberal Party these days who remember them.

Let me outline some of the devious activities of some members-I stress `some'-of the Liberal Party in recent weeks in regard to opposing the hand-over, as they say, of Ayers Rock to Aboriginal owners. I wish to table in the Senate a petition that has been circulated. I regret to say that it came from Townsville. I am ashamed that it came from Townsville because, having been a member of the Townsville City Council, I pride myself on the fact that that council has done much to create recial harmony in an urban area. It was the first council to recognise Aboriginal people and genuinely to work and consult with them within an urban setting. I am not referring to Aboriginal communities. Townsville City Council was the first council to recognise the Aboriginal flag officially and to fly it proudly on National Aborigines Day. It was the first council to appoint an Aboriginal liaison officer so that Aborigines and Islanders in that city could feel that their needs were being considered at the local government level. Therefore, I found it somewhat disheartening that a City Council employee, a solicitor no less, should be the person who somehow got together a group of concerned citizens to dream up this petition for presentation in this place. It just so happens that this solicitor who heads the group of concerned citizens, a Mr John Robinson, is also a prominent Liberal Party member. I know that many of his colleagues this far south are very embarrassed by this document.

Earlier Senator Peter Baume read out the Liberal Party's policy in this respect. He talked about the most disadvantaged group in Australia. He said that all Liberals accepted the policy of the Liberal Party. Yet here is this absolute racist document which essentially came from the Liberal Party. I will read some of the the headlines on the petition:
Land rights have become land wrongs
Ayers Rock belongs to all Australians--
I have heard that phrase somewhere before in debates on this subject--
Land rights have gone too far
We are one nation, one people.
It's time to stand up and be counted, to say ``Enough is enough''.

That petition is a fraud because it has been circulated ostensibly by a group of concerned citizens. Mr Robinson's photograph has been conveniently placed on the petition. It has the Ayers Rock campaign and a post office box number. It would not surprise me if, next time there is a Federal election in the area of Herbert, Mr Robinson, aided and abetted by Paul Everingham, came forward with this sort of policy and this sort of condemnation of the rights of Aboriginal people. Yet Senator Peter Baume said in this place that all Liberals accept the policy of the Liberal Party in regard to their concern for the most disadvantaged Australians. I wonder why we hear continually in this country opposition to land rights when they affect Aborigines. It seems to me that as soon as we mention Aborigines, recognition, land rights and prior ownership there is an outcry from the reactionaries, the Opposition and, regrettably, some members of the community. Obviously those people hold strong views about Austrlaian heritage and land ownership only when the potential owners are Aborigines.

Ayers Rock is a small area of the total Australian land mass. It, of course, will remain a national park with access for all Australians. Yet compare this with the fact that nearly three-quarters of Australian land is owned by a mere 160,000 individuals, families and corporations. This land is privately owned and controlled by a mere one per cent of the total Australian population. Does this create a divided continent? Furthermore, there is no outcry against the extent to which Australian resources are controlled by overseas corporations. Foreign land rights are okay, but Aboriginal land rights apparently threaten the stability of an entire nation. It is hard to believe that any intelligent individual could accept such obvious double standards and irrationality.

This is a typical Bjelke-Petersen double standard in opposing Aboriginal land rights while selling off as much of Queensland as he can to foreign interests. It must continue to be exposed as a total sham. In Queensland, for instance, I know that parts of our most attractive and unique areas are being sold off for as little as $5 a hectare. At a place called Mount Molloy a certain gentleman, who must have had a certain friendly arrangement with the Premier, was able to buy land for as little as $1 a hectare. I am completely disgusted with the type of campaign that has been carried out not just by the Liberal Party. I wonder whether it is being pushed by the National Party of Australia. I have an article from the Sunday Territorian dated 11 August 1985. It is about a Mr Ian Sinclair, the National Party Leader, and is entitled `I'll amend land rights promises Sinclair...'. The article states:
National Party leader, Mr Ian Sinclair, said that he was `ashamed to be a part of the Fraser-Anthony team that brought land rights in 1976'.

Mr Sinclair goes on to state that as far as he is concerned the era of land rights under a National and Liberal Party government is over. There is obviously no future for Aboriginal people's recognition under a National Party-Liberal Party regime.

Now I would like to deal with the fundamentals of this legislation and just run through some facts. There has been precious little in the way of facts in the debate in the House. I presume that in the chamber today we will hear a lot more emotion about our Ayers Rock being spirited away than genuine recognition of the facts as I would like to spell them out now. There is evidence of Aboriginal presence in the area as far back as 10,000 year ago-that is, prehistory. European sightings indicating Aboriginal presence in the area were recorded first by explorers in the 1870s and also by pastoralists in the 1880s. The Petermann Aboriginal reserve was established in 1920 for the protection of Aboriginals inhabiting the area in the general vicinity of Ayers Rock. In 1958 the land now forming the Uluru National Park was excised from the Petermann reserve. Had that land not been excised from the reserve it would have been included in Schedule 1 of the Act, as was the case with other reserves, and granted with the remainder of the land in that reserve in 1978.

The land claim for Uluru-Ayers Rock and the Lake Amadeus Luritja area was lodged in 1979. Before the claim was heard the then Aboriginal Land Commissioner, Mr Justice Toohey, found that as the park was alienated crown land it was not available for claim. During the hearing, however, it was estblished that in relation to two Aboriginal estates in the claim area the most significant sites were located in the park. Those estates were Uluru and Katatjuta. In Mr Justice Toohey's words:

So many witnesses, not merely those belonging to the Ayers Rock estate or to Katatjutanya, spoke about the great significance of both places . . . The attachment of all Aboriginal witnesses to both places was obvious.

Using the rigorous tests to determine traditional ownership contained in the land rights Act, Mr Justice Toohey found 104 traditional owners for the Uluru estate and 57 for the Katatjuta estate in the claim area that extends into the park. Those traditional owners are listed in the Commissioner's report on the Uluru land claim and are a matter of public record.

I would now like to go through some of the conditions and agreements that have already been announced by the Minister in the other place. I refer to the Uluru Board. The agreement reached with the Aboriginals for Uluru National Park provides for the establishment of an Uluru Board of 11 members consisting of six Aboriginals nominated by the traditional owners plus the Director of National Parks and Wildlife, one other Commonwealth official nominated by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, one representative of the tourist industry nominated by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism and two representatives of the Northern Territory. The legislation provides that a majority of members of the Board shall be Aboriginals nominated by the traditional Aboriginal owners and that the Aboriginal representatives should be in a majority at all meetings. The functions of the Board as they relate to Uluru are to prepare, in conjunction with the Director of National Parks and Wildlife, plans of management for the park; to make decisions consistent with the plan of management; to monitor, in conjunction with the Director, the management of the park; and to give advice, in conjunction with the Director, on all aspects of the future development of the park.

It will be obvious to honourable senators that this legislation establishes co-operative management arrangements in which the Director of National Parks and Wildlife and the traditional Aboriginal owners will work in partnership, with the advice of tourist industry and Northern Territory representatives on the board, towards the effective management of Ulura National Park. There will be a plan of management and procedures for development.

Under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act as it now stands the Director of National Parks and Wildlife publicly notifies intent to prepare a plan of management and invites interested persons to make representations; prepares the plan of management, having regard to various objects listed in the Act; publicly notifies that the plan has been prepared and invites interested persons to make representations in connection with the plan; considers the representations and, if he thinks fit, alters the plan accordingly; and submits to the Minister plan, any representations recieved and his comments on those representations. The Minister then accepts the plan or refers it back to the Director together with his suggestions for further consideration. When the Minister accepts the plan the Minister causes it to be laid before both Houses of Parliament. Either House of Parliament may pass a resolution disallowing the plan of management, in which case the Minister instructs the Director to prepare a fresh plan.

The amendments contained in the Bill provide that those steps just described will continue to apply. However, when a board has been established the plan of management will be prepared by the board in conjunction with the director, instead of by the Director. The amendments provide, in the event of a dispute between the Director and the Board during either the preparation or the implementation of the plan of management, for the disagreement to be referred to the Minister for resolution. If the Minister is unable to resolve the disagreement the Minister is required to appoint an arbitrator suitably qualified to deal with the matter impartially and to report to the Minister. The Minister will determine the matter taking into account the arbitrator's findings. The legislation also provides for the Board to make decisions on the management of the park and again provides that the Minister shall have the final say in the event of disagreement between the Director and the Board.

I now refer to the review of the plan and rental. Plans of management will have a maximum term of 10 years. When the board is appointed it will be expected to begin immediately, in conjunction with the Director of National Parks and Wildlife, to draw up a new plan of management for the park. The life of the plan will be addressed during its preparation. The rental will be reviewed whenever the plan of management is rewritten but, in any event, not less frequently than every five years.

The Bill provides for the Minister responsible for the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act to appoint an arbitrator to advise on the resolution of any disagreement between the Director and the board during preparation or implementation of the plan of management. The arbitrator will inquire into the matter and submit a report, together with recommendations, to the Minister. The Minister will then determine the matter, taking account of the arbitrator's findings. The arbitrator is to be a person whom the Minister considers to be suitably qualified and in a position to deal with the matter impartially. The rental is not considered excessive. It will be $75,000 per annum plus 20 per cent of park entrance fees. This is expected to amount to $100,000 per annum, given the present volume of tourist traffic entering the park. The rental, together with opportunities for employment created by the park and associated tourist facilities, is intended to add to the economic base of the Aboriginal community, further enhancing Aboriginal self-determination.

I now refer to the provision of the lease document to Parliament. The memorandum of lease between the Director of National Parks and Wildlife and the Aboriginal land trust which will hold the title for Uluru is still to be finalised with the traditional Aboriginal owners. It will be based on the agreement reached between the Government and Aboriginals. The Government has made public the terms of the agreement, which were summarised in the second reading speech in the House of Representatives. The agreement provides for a 99-year lease; an annual rental of $75,000, et cetera, as I spelt out earlier; an Uluru board comprising six Aboriginals nominated by traditional owners, the Director of National Parks and Wildlife, one Commonwealth official, et cetera; and that the board is to draw up a plan of management for Uluru National Park in conjunction with the Director of National Parks and Wildlife.

The ban on photography in the park is an issue which is continually raised in a most distorted fashion. There is no general ban on photography. To protect the rights to privacy of the Aboriginal people, photography of living areas and sacred sites is not permitted. Guidelines have been established for commercial filming, following a number of incidents in which film crews have been insensitive. Applications for permits to film are assessed against these guidelines, which have been agreed to between the traditional Aboriginal owners, the Director of National Parks and Wildlife, Northern Territory Government agencies and other interested bodies. Most photography in the park proceeds smoothly.

In conclusion, I would like to think that this debate can continue today on a little more rational basis. I would like to hear members of the Opposition acknowledge the complete about-turn and contradictions that have occurred, particularly from Mr Paul Everingham. I would also like them to consider the double standards that are practised when it comes to national parks, particularly by the Queensland National Party, such as the wholesale availability of Hamilton Island on the Great Barrier Reef. I do not remember the people of Queensland rising up in horror when Hamilton Island was allowed to be developed as a tourist resort by a well-known entrepreneur at very favourable original rates. He had a very good deal from the Queensland Government, the sort of deal that Aboriginal people do not get. If Keith Williams from Hamilton Island on our Great Barrier Reef can get that sort of deal and there is no criticism-rather it is said that it works in harmony-why cannot the same sort of standards apply to Aboriginals and Ayers Rock?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two Bills which are before us-the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Amendment Bill and the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill-proceed in the form in which they do as a result of the total confusion in which this Government finds itself over the issue of Aboriginal land rights policy in Australia. They proceed from a determination on the part of the Government to try, by a series of merely symbolic actions, to overcome the facts, which are known both in the Aboriginal community and in the rest of the Australian community, that its successive spokesman and Ministers for Aboriginal Affairs have been failures, that its policy is discredited and, indeed, that it has proceeded to betray, to lie to, to mislead and to deceive Aboriginal people in Australia.
—We have had only one Minister.

—The Minister for Education, sitting in this chamber, is part and parcel of that process-the deception and deceit in the promises made to Aboriginal people and the way in which they have been dishonoured. An attempt is now made by some sort of symbolic gesture to restore the Government's credibility with sections of the Australian electorate whom it misled in the past.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. Because of the complexity of the sentence it has taken me a moment to work out whether to take a point of order.
—What is your point of order?

—I believe that Senator Puplick is guilty of accusing Senator Ryan of being part of a process which he described earlier in the sentence as including lying. It is unparliamentary to use that language in relation to a member of the Senate.
—I did not hear that allegation made. I rule that there is no point of order.

—I am quite happy to allow the facts to speak for themselves. The Bills proceed on the basis of changing the way in which Aboriginal land rights decisions have been made in the past. The way in which those decisions have been made in the past has largely commanded bipartisan support and the support of the Australian community in general. That process has been to have a hearing before the Aboriginal Land Commissioner as provided for under the legislation, for a determination by that independent judicial officer, for a report to go to the Minister and for the Minister to make a decision based upon that expert and other advice. In this case we have a series of circumstances in which certain reports have been provided, including one by Mr Justice Toohey, dealing with claims to Uluru. The Commissioner specifically excluded from his considerations the areas which are now brought back into the Parliament by separate legislation, to be handed to the people who are alleged to be the traditional owners.

SPEECH.PARA: There are certain reasons for having bypassed the established, proven and accepted way in which this matter has been dealt with in the past. Senator Reynolds made accusations that there are contradictions in our approach to this matter. The greatest of all contradictions however is the one from which this legislation proceeds, namely, that after a hearing before the Land Commissioner and a determination by the Land Commissioner in regard to Uluru all of the established practices of dealing with land rights claims are now to be set to one side and a specific, separate, different, one-off arrangement made for purely symbolic purposes. This derives, as I said, from the cave-in on the five `immutable' principles enunciated by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, most of which have now been put to one side, and from the continued criticism within the Australian Labor Party from the Premier of Western Australia and others about the way in which this matter and land rights legislation as a whole have been proceeded with. It is no wonder, therefore, that in the fourth annual report of the Central Land Council, for 1983-84, the Council, commenting on the way in which this Government's land rights legislation was being managed, said:
The Council is very dissatisfied with the lack of progress in the processing of land claims in its area during 1983-84.
The Central Land Council itself is highly critical of the failure of the Government to process the legislation and the claims made under that legislation.

There is no doubt that the term `Aboriginal land rights' has led not only to a great deal of emotion but also to a great deal of misunderstanding, particularly when applied in individual cases. I well recall the problems encountered in the 1969-70 period, when I was on the staff of the first Commonwealth Minister in charge of aboriginal affairs, the Hon. Bill Wentworth, in attempting to define what was meant by the word `Aboriginal', how extensive that term was and how it should be defined.

If anything has given credence to the proposition that this is becoming an increasingly difficult matter to determine it is the way in which we have proceeded with this piece of legislation. The Minister, in his second reading speech, stated that the legislation is to:

. . . enable implementation of the Government's decision to grant the land in the Uluru . . . National Park to an Aboriginal land trust and implementation of the agreement with the Aboriginal traditional owners . . .

If one thing can be established it is that the Mutitjulu community is not necessarily the same as the Aboriginal traditional owners. When this matter came before the Land Rights Commissioner three particular groups were recognised as being the traditional owners of the area in question and they were members of the Pitjantjatjara, the Jankuntjatjara and the Matuntara clans or linguistic groups. Those three groups were identified by the Aboriginal Land Rights Commissioner and in his report on the Uluru claim honourable senators will see a list of some 160 named persons. A degree of confusion arises in this area. For instance, it is known that the Jankuntjatjara people have been in the area, certainly in an identifiable form, as far back as 1896. But the Pitjantjatjara people, who were recognised as being part of the claimant process, have been in that part of Central Australia probably for less than a generation. Therefore the question of how this extraordinary body-the Mutitjulu organisation-can be said to represent the traditional owners when it does not comprise exclusively representatives of the groups previously identified as being potentially the recognised traditional Aboriginal owners of the area, I think, creates an extraordinary and unsound precedent in the handling of land rights claims. I will come back to that matter later.

The second point I make is that in this legislation we have moved a long way from the determination about land and its significance which was laid so clearly by His Honour Mr Justice Blackburn when he pronounced his judgment in the case of Milirrpum and others v.
