The level of productivity under the payment for result system is also much higher than it is under the tally system. The arrangement reached between the Pendarvises and their employees was one which would have allowed the abattoir to operate viably. It would not have gone the way of other meatworks in this country, many of which have closed because of the incredible operating cost of slaughtering a beast under the tally system of $158 per head as against $34 per head under the payment for result system. However, the dispute goes further than that. Primary producers have a market. Nothing would be left for them if it cost some $158 per head to kill a beast. It is incredible that today we have this dispute at Mudginberri. It is killing the industry and a young couple who are pioneers and at the same time hundreds of meat workers are without jobs. I can assure honourable senators that the situation will get worse due to the simple fact that abattoirs in the country are now becoming more and more uneconomic under the tally system.

It is difficult to believe that the Federal Government, and for that matter the unions, cannot see the merit in the system which was operating at Mudginberri. It is difficult to believe that they cannot see the potential for employers and employees to come together to negotiate their wage or salary arrangements to their mutual satisfaction and within the award set down by the Arbitration Commission-within the laws of the land. It is even more difficult to believe that the Federal Government prefers to establish a practice of allowing unions to ignore the decisions of the Arbitration Commission and the Federal Court but that, it seems, is the case. That is why we are giving this problem an airing in the Senate today.

There is no question that both the employer and the employees are morally and legally entitled to proceed with the agreement which they have reached but they are being thwarted by the union. The union is using strong arm tactics and has the obvious support-this has been seen-of the ACTU which, obviously, is out to crush the young couple, the Pendarvises, in Arnhem Land. As I have said, we have had no constructive action from Mr Kerin despite the fact that he stated unequivocally on the Four Corners program that the activities of the AMIEU in this dispute are illegal.

Mr Kerin's refusal to confront the issue is in line with the weak, servile and negligent approach which has been taken by many of his colleagues. Many Ministers in the Federal Government are involved in this issue in various ways. For instance, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, has recently indicated that he wishes to see the matter referred back to the Arbitration Commission. He is attempting to pass the responsibility for the dispute to the Commission and so absolve the Government of its responsibilities. The responsibility lies in the hands of the Government. The Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, seems to have no regard for the fact that the Pendarvises and Australia stand to lose a lucrative overseas market.

The contribution of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the dispute has been even less. The only time he has been involved in any way in this dispute was when a private and confidential letter stating the terms of settlement proposed to him by Mudginberri on 12 August turned up in the union ranks, with the AMIEU. I am not suggesting that the Prime Minister would have leaked this confidential document but it did go to his office. I wonder why and how such a confidential document turned up in the hands of the union which is the cause of all the problems. It is a most peculiar situation.

As I have said, all Ministers are avoiding the issue because they know that they simply cannot handle the union movement. This Government has made a lot of its accord and its ability to manage economic policy because of its special relationship with the trade union movement. That special relationship is good only as long as the trade unions want it to be. Comes the showdown and the Government buckles or merely refuses to tackle the issue. This is exactly the situation which applies today in regard to the Mudginberri dispute.

The dispute at Mudginberri has indeed been very revealing. It has put the lie to the Government's claims of being able to deal with the unions on the basis of consensus. It puts the lie to the Government's claim of being able to deal with the unions at all. The Government's failure to deal with the issues raised by the Mudginberri dispute is like its problems with the ACTU over tax reform. It is only the beginning of its problems with the unions and that will mark the beginning of the end of the Labor Government. Let us have a little sanity regarding this dispute. We all realise-I have said this before-that unionism is a good thing. It has brought many things for the workers of Australia but it is being abused now by the AMIEU.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin by summarising some parts of the speech of the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations and employment in another place. In a speech he gave in Katherine in the Northern Territory on Saturday, 10 August, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In the meantime, let me clearly state to Jay Pendarvis, his employees at Mudginberri, the Meat and Allied Trades Federation and the NFF in this dispute you have the Federal Opposition's unqualified support.

Firstly, is it not wonderful that in an area so complex as industrial relations, in an area where changing work practices are already being negotiated, discussed and debated someone could be as sure about where he stands as that? If that sort of person can do this with every dispute and be so sure about where he stands and so sure about solutions, obviously that person has a long career in industrial relations ahead of him and should never have been in this Parliament in the first place. In fact, he should be working as an industrial relations expert for one of the major companies. Surely such companies would be prepared to snap him up, as no doubt they will after the next election when he loses his seat. I do not want to take this chamber up the old fashioned track where we find Mr Shack's old fashioned ideas.

We ought to look at what this dispute represents. We are not talking about just one dispute. I agree with the Opposition that it is in some ways a symbolic dispute. Of course, it is being made symbolic by the Opposition's activity both in the Northern Territory and in this chamber. We are talking about the future of an orderly and fair labour relations system which has existed in this country since 1904. It is not the Government that is under attack today. It is not the meatworkers' union which is under attack. The Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the Australian industrial relations system are under attack. That system has worked quite well over a long period for the benefit of both employers and employees. From where does this attack come? It comes from the Liberal-National Party Opposition, the same people who brought us the great wages explosion of 1981-82, who brought us four different and failed industrial relations Ministers, one of whom is their current leader. Between 1979 and 1982-just three years-we saw four of them go down the chute because they were unable to handle the mess into which they had placed themselves. They brought us an inflation rate of 12 per cent and left government at a time when there were 733,000 unemployed. They were finally and justifiably thrown out by the electors.

Members of the Opposition pretend to give us advice about the way to handle industrial relations. That comes at a time when industrial relations in this country have improved dramatically. Let us look at this matter in the simple terms of the number of days lost through industrial diputes. We have the best record for 16 years. Take it from the final year of the Liberal-National Party Government. In 1982 there were 4,564 days lost per thousand; in 1983, the next year and our first year of government, the figure dropped form 4,564 to 1,801; in 1984 it dropped to 1,572; and in 1985 at the end of January-these are all comparable end of January figures-the figure was 1,326. That is a dramatic and consistent drop over three years. That did not happen by accident. It happened because of the way this Government has been involved in the industrial relations game and the way it has handled industrial relations. It is the fruit of the arrangements that we made before we came to office. It is the fruit of the accord and a positive and properly negotiated arrangement and approach to industrial relations.

This attack on the system comes at a time when the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems has just presented its report on the future workings of the system. That Committee consisted of some of the best industrial relations brains in the country and rejected the whole idea of deregulation of the industrial relations system. It said basically that we should have more of the same with amendments and improvements to the current system. It rejected out of hand the calls for the abolition of the arbitration system and for total deregulation of the labour market which have been made so often by the Opposition.

We have to look at this matter in political terms because this is basically what the debate is about today. It is not an industrial relations matter in the minds of the Opposition. Why is it a political matter? Why has the subject of industrial relations suddenly been put on the agenda? It is because the Federal Opposition at the moment is short of places to go. This Government-basically a conservative, reform oriented government-has taken the middle ground, the common sense ground, on so many issues in political life and it has left the Opposition with nowhere to go. We have floated the dollar so that it has found its true value and Australian exporters have benefited from that true value and from the extra competitiveness that it has given us. We have allowed foreign banks to come into the country to create competition and to give our exporters a base abroad.

These are two things of many which John Howard would have liked to do but was not able to get through his own party because of the ineptness and, I must say, the cowardice of many of his colleagues. He failed where we have succeeded in doing what should have been done a long time ago. So where does the Opposition go? It has gone back to the bare shelf of ideas to look for something that will distinguish it from our Government, from the common sense middle ground. It has looked at the shelf labelled `Deregulation of the Labour Market'. The Opposition has picked that up because it knows that we as a government will not move in that direction. For good basic economic and humanitarian reasons we will not touch deregulation of the labour market. We have made that clear.

What is the Opposition's model? The problem with the Opposition is that it has two models for the appropriate way to move down the industrial relations track. The first is a very authoritarian and paternalistic model that has been born out of the Queensland situation. In fact, if we look at the appropriate motions moved in the Senate we will see that Senator MacGibbon, for example, has moved that we should follow the Singapore model of industrial relations-the Singapore model for heaven's sake. We all know what that means for the very existence of the trade union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —A one-parliament model.

—Yes, it is a one-parliament model and a one-union model-the official union. It is basically an authoritarian model. I will not spend too much time on it. It is not worthy of it. We should consign it to the scrap-heap in the same way as the fancy theories about the hydrogen car and Milan Brych and other viewpoints of the Queensland Premier ought to be consigned to the dust-bin. We will leave that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a second string to the Opposition's bow that we should look at. In many ways that string is quite different from the first. It is total deregulation. We move from paternalism to de-regulation. What do we see? We see the Opposition pushing the American model of collective bargaining. That is what its support of the dispute at Mudginberri is all about. It is to give it the opportunity to push the idea of the abolition of the Arbitration Commission and of our industrial relations system. It is an interesting but an alien idea that does not fit into the Australian social and industrial environment. It is about as relevant as Ronald Reagan's hair oil. It is not suitable for this country. The people who know that this is irrelevant, who have to practise within the system, who have to make profits in their business, the workers whose unions are representing them, know that the American model will not work in this country.

Let us look at some matters. As part of the symbolism there was a visit to Mudginberri the other week by that wonderful quartet, Shack, Sinclair, Everingham and Senator Kilgariff. Someone described them as the butcher shop quartet. That is quite appropriate because when they went there they sang like birds about deregulation and the loss of liberty by the owner and employees.

What were they trying to do? They wanted to lift the whole issue to the symbolic status that it is achieving today. But it will not move on because the rest of the industry and business organisations, and the unions that have to work in this current system, will not cop an alien system-one that the Liberal Party Opposition wants to transplant from America. Why will they not cop that? They know that in a country where 50 per cent of the workforce is unionised it is just not possible to go down the same track as was followed in America, where something like 18 per cent of the work force is unionised and where even in the best years following the Wagner Act less than 30 per cent of the work force was unionised.

Do people want to go down the track of the United Kingdom? Again, people in this country have too much common sense to follow that track. They saw what happened with the miners strike in Great Britain-a dispute which went on for a year, which is still simmering and which left a legacy of nastiness and bitterness that I do not think that industry will get over for a long time. They saw the coal strike in Britain in 1971-a six-month strike that again brought Britain to its knees. They saw the Post Office strike that went on for six to seven months in Britain and which left Britain almost totally without telecommunications and postal services. Those people in industry are not fools. They have watched the failure of deregulation in other countries. They have watched the failure of collective bargaining in other countries and they are not going to have it here.

In case the Opposition does not get around amongst the business community-and from where I have been in the last month or so my guess is that it has not been getting around-let me tell the Opposition that the business community in this country, let alone anyone else, will not tolerate this move towards deregulation. They know that track is an American model that is not suited to this particular country. Think about that because if one tries to change the industrial relations system in this country-and basically that is what this debate is all about-one has to be prepared to follow a track that is much harder, tougher and bloodier than it would be in other countries. It was easy to do it in the United States where the history of trade unionism is very tenuous. It is fairly easy to do it in Britain because the institutional structures in Great Britain make it possible to make attacks on the union movement and get away with it. There will be social dislocation and enormous damage to the British economy, but one can get away with it in many ways.

That will not happen in this country. The trade union movement is institutionalised in a commonsense way, in a way that has worked significantly and well for over 80 years and the trade union movement is not going to give up the sort of benefits that occur under this system. Employers are not going to give up the sort of benefits that occur under this system. Therefore, if we follow that other track we are heading for disaster in this country. The warning is there.

The National Farmers Federation, alone amongst employers as a major national organisation, is not heeding that advice. It does not see the writing on the wall. I conclude with a quote from the Age newspaper of 16 August because I think it puts it quite succinctly. In a sense I think it categorises all those people dealing in symbolism when they talk about industrial relations, those people who live in cloud cuckoo land and who are prepared to take that leap into the dark that deregualtion of the labour market would be all about. I quote:
At the moment, the NFF is fighting to the last drop of someone else's blood. It might not be so brave when its blood, and that of hundreds of individual employers, is on the floor.

The Age was speaking metaphorically, but can we afford as a country the sort of dislocation and damage that will occur if we follow the other track of deregulation which is what this motion is designed to create a climate for.

The Government, I think through the Department of Health in particular, has put something like $7m into the development of a malaria vaccine which will have not only world-wide implications in terms of public health but also in terms of the revenue that can potentially be derived for Australia and which I think would be one of our most significant high technology exports. We as parliamentarians must understand that water, and its careful management, are of paramount importance in Australia. Rainfall in this country is both uneven and low, and there are few natural streams. Droughts are ever-present. The report by the Institute of Freshwater Studies deals with an area that is of the utmost importance to Australia, namely, management and handling of freshwaters. Water is used in all aspects of agriculture. Without water the dairying, livestock, citrus and wine growing industries in my State would quickly fold. In urban areas we need quality water. Water is extremely important in tourism, and is also an essential part of health and welfare. We need to manage pollution in water. We need to manage planning for drought and environmental degradation, to the areas surrounding our rivers and streams. We need to manage our underground water resources.

The Murray-Darling basin covers four States. South Australia depends on water from the River Murray. Some 80 per cent of this is surface water and 50 per cent of the total use of water in South Australia comes from the Murray. The town of Whyalla and the northern towns are wholly dependent upon the River Murray for their water. The income from irrigation in the basin is estimated at $350m per annum. The cost of salinity control currently is around $60m. The total estimated cost of the Institute to handle research for this area was estimated at only $5m per annum, and yet the Interim Council decided to recommend against such a proposal. A vast number of bodies, authorities and research organisations handle the subject of water. As such we need a focus. The operation proposed by the Government is to institute an Australian Water Research Advisory Council and a National Water Resources, Assessment program whose functions are purely advisory and for funding distribution. This is apparently going to cost an amount of $0.7m and these bodies will not carry out any research in their own right. There is also the proposal that $0.8m should be provided for the Till laboratory at Albury-Wodonga and $2.5m for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and other research organisations.

It is pleasing to note that $8m may be distributed to sundry other laboratories through the water research assistance fund. If the Minister for Resources and Energy approves! However, I believe that both the co-ordination through this administrative body and the various activities that are being carried on within the CSIRO and the universities are quite insufficient and I recommend to the Government that it consider a centre of excellence which deals with the whole area of water research. There are so many areas and strands to be brought together. We have to compare our situation with that of Canada, Holland, the United Kingdom, South Africa, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and Spain, which all have national organisations to co-ordinate their water resources. Water is Australia's scarcest resource. Surely it deserves research, management and information services of world class and excellence. A centre for this could be the Institute of Freshwater Studies. The Interim Council and now the Government recommended against it, and I deplore their decision.

This is an issue highlighted in the 1983-84 annual reports of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and the Australian Children's Television Foundation.

My remarks today concern the second report in the series. Before I discuss the second report, however, I should express the Committee's appreciation of the prompt response made by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) to its first report. The first report recommended that the Minister for Education should determine whether the Australian Capital Territory Apprenticeship Board is subject to the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act (No. 1) 1983. It recommended that, if this were the case, the Board should be directed to conform to the provisions of the Act regarding the furnishing of annual reports. Honourable senators will know that the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act (No. 1) requires statutory bodies, which are obliged to produce annual reports, to furnish those reports within six months of the end of their accounting period. In a letter dated 30 May 1985, only 15 days after the Committee's report was tabled, the Minister stated that the Australian Capital Territory apprenticeship board is subject to the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act and that she would inform the Board accordingly. The Minister also stated that even if the Board were not subject to the Act she would still insist that it report within six months. On behalf of the Committee I thank the Minister for her rapid response to the first report.

The second report in this series sets out the Committee's views about what should be included in the annual reports of government agencies. The report is intended primarily for the guidance of those statutory authorities and government departments whose annual reports are referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts. In its report, the Committee has drawn attention to the various guidelines for the production of annual reports set down by the Commonwealth Government, the Australian Institute of Management and the Royal Australian Institute of Public Administration. In the Committee's opinion, compliance with the Commonwealth Government guidelines should be the minimum goal for all government agencies preparing annual reports for 1984-85. Government departments and larger statutory corporations, especially those engaged in commercial activities, should aim at meeting the more elaborately defined criteria suggested by the Australian Institute of Management and the Royal Australian Institute of Public Administration.

In this report, the Committee has also examined in detail the 1983-84 annual report of the Australian Bicentennial Authority. This examination was based on the Commonwealth Government guidelines and was undertaken to give an example of the Committee's approach. The report concludes with comments on the timeliness of annual reports on the operation of certain Acts of Parliament. These comments could not be included in the first report because the information was not then available.

Mr President, I regret to report that the Committee's examination of 33 annual reports has shown that few government agencies appear to appreciate the value of their annual reports. Good annual reports contribute significantly to the public's understanding of the achievements and difficulties of government agencies. They also facilitate parliamentary scrutiny of the activities of the Executive Government. For these reasons, government agencies should take seriously the production of their annual reports. They should allocate sufficient resources to this activity to ensure that annual reports of a high standard are produced as soon as possible after the end of the reporting period.

Although the standard of most annual reports remains inadequate in many respects, the Committee's work suggests that there has been some improvement in recent years. This has been due in no small measure to the activities of bodies such as the Australian Institute of Management and the Royal Australian Institute of Public Administration. The work of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations has also been influential. Finally, I should pay tribute to those officers within the reporting agencies who have been directly responsible for the improvements in reporting. No doubt standards of reporting will continue to improve. To encourage this trend, the Standing Committee on Education and the Arts will continue to monitor the standards of annual reporting of those government agencies whose reports are referred to it. The Committee intends in future to report at least annually on the standards of presentaition and timely submission of annual reports. I commend the report to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY AND TRADE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Senator Archer:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity to discuss briefly some of the conclusions in the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade second report into the closer economic relations trade agreement between Australia and New Zealand. At the outset, let me say that the New Zealanders have developed a far more effective negotiating style. As a result, the New Zealanders have been rewarded for their efforts under the CER trade agreement. On the other hand, in the lead-up to and since the commencement of the agreement, Australians have taken a rather indifferent approach to CER. Unfortunately, for many industries and regions, this has meant that CER has only become an issue after certain New Zealand products have begun to have an impact on the Australian market. This has led to a rather negative and at times adverse reaction by Australians to CER. This only highlights the fact that had Australia spent a little more time and effort and generated more community interest and discussion during the lead-up to CER, it is quite possible a number of problems and concerns that are being raised may have been avoided or at least minimised. We cannot turn back the clock, but what Australia now has to do is to win back some of the lost ground and ensure that the agreement does precisely what it was meant to do.

SPEECH.PARA: The four main objectives under the CER trade agreement are: To strengthen the broader relationship between Australia and New Zealand; to develop closer economic relations between member States through a mutually beneficial expansion of free trade between New Zealand and Australia; to eliminate barriers to trade between Australia and New Zealand in a gradual and progressive manner under an agreed timetable and with a minimum of disruption; and to develop trade between Australia and New Zealand under conditions of fair competition. The nature and intent of the agreement are quite clear. However, in practice, the Committee believes that some of these objectives are not being met.

The apparent eagerness by both parties to replace the ailing New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement with a more comprehensive trade agreement resulted in the implementation of CER with a large number of modified arrangements as well as a number of deferrals. This decision has caused, and will continue to cause, a misallocation of resources and this has placed added burdens on those sectors which are already operating in a completely free trade environment.

CER lacks a plan or strategy for the future development of industries and regions in both countries. In particular, no mechanisms are in place to evaluate whether or not the objectives are being achieved. It appears that both governments have opted to wait to see how trade develops and, at the same time, both are hoping that there will be very few transitional problems at either an industry or regional level. The Committee, however, sees the need to have in place clearer guidelines which incorporate general industry and regional outcomes. If both parties are predicting significant benefits from CER, it would seem logical to ask where these benefits will occur.

Australia and New Zealand have begun a process of freeing up trade across the Tasman at a time when the rest of the world is still putting in place more obstacles to trade. Even though both Australia and New Zealand are members of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the Committee finds it most disturbing that the long term success of CER could be severely jeopardised by the inability of GATT to enforce its rules on some of the more powerful member nations.

The Committee is not convinced that CER as it presently exists is providing a climate of certainty from the point of business investment on both sides of the Tasman. On the contrary, the Committee believes that one of the most fundamental uncertainties surrounding the future success and direction of CER is just how far and how quickly New Zealand will proceed with the dismantling of its global import licensing system and whether or not this system will be replaced with a new system of tariffs.

The Committee would therefore have expected consideration of the following: An assessment of whether or not CER would provide the right sorts of market signals to ensure the expansion of both countries' efficient and low cost industries; a full documentation of the types and levels of assistance that will still be in place in both countries after the staged removal of tariffs, quantitative restrictions and export incentives; and the commissioning of a number of impact studies for the various industry sectors in order to gain a clear, but not necessarily precise, picture of the likely areas of expansion and contraction.

Turning specifically to some of the shortcomings under CER, the Committee believes firstly that the safeguard provisions as they presently exist offer very little recourse to any party who may be suffering geniune hardship and injury arising from CER. Secondly, anti-dumping and countervailing inquiries continue to be lengthy, the determination of normal value and injury still causes concern and the additional consultative processes that have been built into CER appear to exacerbate matters further. Thirdly, other safeguard provisions, namely articles 17 and 22, are very vague and ineffective and therefore appear to offer very little comfort to anyone who wishes to pursue a genuine grievance. Fourthly, other articles under CER covering such aspects as intermediate goods, rules of origin, et cetera are reactive rather than trying to eliminate the source of the problem.

Since the commencement of CER, exchange rates have fluctuated, both suddenly and widely. From 1980 to the beginning of this year, New Zealand's real exchange rate has fallen relative to Australia's, thus enhancing its competitive position. In the past few months the pendulum has swung the other way. The July 1984 20 per cent devaluation of the New Zealand dollar caused a great deal of concern in Australia because this action made many goods in Australia virtually uncompetitive overnight. The adoption of floating exchange rate policies by both governments has certainly removed the possibility of any further major one-off currency realignments. However, it is difficult to say whether or not the continual daily adjustments to each currency will be less disruptive to trade compared with earlier exchange rate policies of both countries. In particular, because our exchange rates are largely determined by factors exogenous to CER, trans-Tasman trade is likely to be disrupted from time to time.

Finally, whilst it may seem that the Committee is being highly critical of many aspects of the CER agreement, it nevertheless believes that if both countries want to fulfil the CER objectives, it would appear that more active consideration must be given to the issues raised in the Committee's second report and, hopefully, that these matters will be resolved as soon as possible and not be put to one side until the 1988 review.

I commend the report to the Senate. I would like to take the opportunity to express my gratitude to the many people who have made a deep contribution to the preparation of the report and the job that is ahead of us, particularly Mr Peter Keele, the Secretary of the Committee, and the Committee staff. The preparation of the report has been a great effort. We have had complete co-operation from people from both sides of the Tasman who are highly desirous of getting the CER agreement working as it was intended to work.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 August, on motion by Senator Georges:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the Senate will have an opportunity to have a brief debate on this matter. I trust that some facility will be given to others to participate, having in mind that we have some time left-
—There are 43 minutes left for this debate, Senator.

—We are fortunate that we do not have three minutes. I just indicate that to those who have an interest in entering into the debate. The report entitled `Export of Live Sheep from Australia' is the first of a series of reports on particular aspects of the inquiry of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare into the question of animal welfare in Australia. This report was approved by the original four members of the Committee prior to the retirement from the Senate of Senators Jack Evans, Jean Hearn and Doug Scott after 30 June this year. I wish to pay tribute to the dedication of these three senators to the task of finalising this unanimous report prior to their retirement. At this stage I would like also to acknowledge the work of the Secretary of the Committee, Mr Paul Barsdell, his assistant, Jim Warner, and Louise Hildyard and Leone Peake and the other staff members of the Committee in producing this first report of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: In recent years, the live sheep export trade has been criticised strongly by animal welfare and veterinary organisations and has been beset with serious industrial problems. After preliminary public hearings in May 1984, the Committee decided to give priority to the examination of the animal welfare issues associated with the live sheep export trade. It is also accorded priority to kangaroo management. The keeping of whales and dolphins in captivity was added to that priority list later in that year. The Committee received written submissions and took oral evidence from Federal and State Government authorities, the industry, animal welfare organisations and other people. It also visited two live sheep carriers and four export feedlots to gain some first hand experience of the trade.

The first three chapters of the report are introductory. The next seven examine the welfare aspects of each stage of the export trade. This is followed by four chapters on economic factors and a general chapter on research. The final chapter states the Committee's main conclusions and deals with the general administration of the trade. This report, together with the submissions and the evidence taken, represents a very clear analysis of the trade and is worthy of study by those who are interested in the trade as it exists and in its future. At the front of the report is a restatement of the general conclusions drawn by the Committee in chapter 16. This is followed by a list of recommendations made by the Committee, with the relevant paragraph number alongside each.
I shall now comment briefly on the main conclusions and recommendations contained in the report.

The Committee reached the conclusion that, on purely animal welfare grounds, there is enough evidence to stop the trade. As stated in the report, the trade is, in many respects, inimical to good animal welfare, and it is not in the interests of the animal to be transported to the Middle East for slaughter.

The Committee acknowledged that animal welfare aspects could not be divorced from economic and other factors. All these factors were considered by the Committee. The Committee went on to say in the report:

After consideration of all factors, the Committee acknowledges the reality of the situation that any short-term cessation or disruption to the trade would cause considerable dislocation both in Australia and in the Middle East. Consequently, the Committee agrees that the trade will continue for some years and insists that significant improvements be made to animal welfare in many areas of the trade as recommended in this report.

The implementation of reforms will help to reduce but not eliminate stress, suffering and risk during transportation of sheep to the Middle East. Therefore a long-term solution must be sought. The substitution of the refrigerated sheepmeat trade for the live export trade offers such a solution. The Federal Government should promote and encourage the expansion of the refrigerated sheepmeat trade to the Middle East and other countries, with the aim of eventually substituting it for the live sheep trade.

The Committee received serious criticisms of the administration of the live sheep export trade. It became clear that: Animal health and welfare was often overridden by economic expediency; standards of inspection varied considerably among the States; the Australian Agricultural Health and Quarantine Service, formerly the Australian Bureau of Animal Health, was unable to give enough attention to the supervision and co-ordination of inspections conducted on its behalf by State veterinary quarantine officers; and the legislative basis of the inspection service was tenuous.

The Committee did not believe that self-regulation has worked or will work without adequate regulatory supervision. It has therefore recommended that Federal legislation be enacted to give the Australian Agricultural Health and Quarantine Service more powers to supervise the health and welfare of export sheep from the time of receival at an export feedlot to loading on board a carrier. The Committee also supported the continuation of the existing arrangement whereby the State veterinary officers act for the Federal Government.

The Committee recommended that export feedlots be licensed by State governments based on standards to be drawn up by the Australian Agricultural Health and Quarantine Service, in consultation with the State departments of agriculture and the Australian Livestock Exporters Association.
I have one or two comments to make and my time is running out. Therefore, I seek leave to incorporate the rest of the statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

There are a number of other recommendations made in the report which deal with specific aspects of feedlots. One such recommendation relates to the adequate provision of shelter at feedlots. There was an appalling dust problem during the Committee's visit to the levels feedlot north of Adelaide in March this year. The weather conditions were extraordinary at the time but the Committee noted that little attention had been paid to the provision of shelter. Last week, between 500 and 1000 goats and sheep died in a cold snap in the same feedlot. Obviously, something needs to be done about the provision of shelter at that feedlot and probably at others.

Towards the end of the public hearings, the Australian Agricultural Health and Quarantine Service gave details of a pilot program of government veterinarians accompanying 20 to 30 per cent of shipments of live sheep to the Middle East. This program will not only provide much essential information for research but it will also enable the number of sheep mortalities onboard carriers to be verified by an independent person. The Committee strongly supported this program and recommended that the Service give high priority to its implementation.

A number of recommendations were directed at the need for research. Until recently, little research had been conducted into problems encountered within the trade. Most of that research has been carried out by individual companies and not published. Even now, the amount of research is totally inadequate, and more funds need to be channelled into research projects in specific areas of the trade. The Committee found a lack of statistics on sheep mortalities in the trade. Those which were available were regarded, even by government authorities, as being unreliable. Recommendations have been made in relation to the keeping and analysis of statistics.

The Committee will monitor during the rest of the inquiry the action taken by the Federal and State governments and the industry in relation to the Committee's recommendations. Later this year, the Committee will present to the Senate a report on whales and dolphins in captivity and then one on kangaroos. Once these two reports have been presented, the Committee will examine animal experimentation and other areas of the inquiry. I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason I incorporated the statement was to give me an opportunity to make one or two comments concerning the reporting of the Committee's report by the media. Because of the desire of the industry to have a report put down as soon as possible, with the authority of the Senate, it was released last week. As I said yesterday, the conclusions and recommendations appear to have been Delphic in their style. I have never seen such a varied reporting of conclusions and recommendations by the media. I have a list of the reports and each one varies. My concern is that there has been misrepresentation of a question asked and an answer given by me at a Press conference. It was reported as if it appeared that the recommendation of the Committee was that the trade be phased out in five to seven years. I was asked the question: `If it were to be phased out, how long would that take?' I indicated that if that decision were made, or words to that effect, it would take five to seven years. That was reported as a recommendation of the Committee in one of the newspapers.

SPEECH.PARA: That report led to a considerable number of protests, one of which came from the National Farmers Federation. The Federation wrote a letter, which it issued publicly before it reached me, in which Mr Ian McLachlan, the President of the National Farmers Federation, made certain caustic comments about my lack of responsibility. Since the Committee will need to deal and consult with the National Farmers Federation regarding a number of references that it still has before it, I hope that this will not prejudice the work of the Committee or the understanding of the National Farmers Federation of the care that the Committee will take with all its references.

I apologise to former Senator Scott who may have been similarly misled by this misreporting. For that reason I say to him that my position is the position of the report. My position is the position of the statement made to the Senate. It would be wise for people to look at the report itself and the statement which has been made and draw their conclusions from those, not from any Press statement concerning the report. Mr Acting Deputy President, I thank you for your courtesy in allowing me to say a few extra words beyond my time. I commend the report to the Senate. I advise all honourable senators and those interested in the industry to read it carefully and thoroughly and perhaps come to the same conclusions as we did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the explanation given by Senator Georges is accepted by me. But I would like to make a few points about about the live sheep export trade because it is of such importance to Australia as over seven million sheep are sold annually and it brings something like $200m of income from overseas. I think the worry, dismay and concern of the people in that industry that were caused by the misreporting, as the honourable senator has just told us it was, should be noted. This is important not only to the committee system of the Senate, which I think works admirably and which is of such importance to the people of Australia; it is equally important how statements which are put in the Press are interpreted by people in that live sheep export trade. I think journalists must be aware of the economic consequences of their over-zealous desires and at times the lack of alternative angles for a story. That aspect worries me. Because of the concern this matter caused Senator Scott, who was a member of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, I will quote from the Press release he put out on 15 August which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . today he very much regretted the confusion brought about by the Chairman of the Committee, Senator George Georges, when he expressed a personal view on the phasing out and specified time interval of the live sheep export trade.
`Such a determination was not the Committee's,' former Senator Scott said.

`On the contrary, the Committee observed the very significant progress in the research, development and facility of the trade, acknowledged its very great economic significance and saw no way in which it should be aboloished in the foreseeable future.

`The Committee agreed that if alternative markets ultimately were found, of equal or greater value to the Australian sheep industry and all those who depend on it, then of course a change of emphasis may appear.
`It is regrettable that such distortion was created from a personal opinion of the Chairman, and not an opinion endorsed by the Committee as a whole.'
As I said, I accept Senator Georges's statement that what he said was completely misrepresented by the Press.

The point about the report to which I would like to refer is the fact that the Committee said that maybe at a future time we could sell chilled mutton to the Middle East. Of course, this is not really the desire of the people in the Middle East who buy that mutton. If that happened I think that trade would fall away dramatically. Religious personal preferences currently preclude that happening. Therefore, I think we must ensure that we have as efficient and humane a trade as possible. I was not a part of this Committee, but I believe that the people who served on it have come up with a finding, on behalf of the live sheep export trade, that is suitable to all people within that trade. I have already said that industry changes should be made in some areas and those changes are actually happening at the moment in relation to the handling, feeding and housing of sheep. But, of course, this does not preclude the improvements that will be made in the future because of this report to the Senate. I say again that I hope that in the future reports which are given to the Senate do not cause as much worry and dismay to the people in an industry which is being investigated, as the misreporting of this report caused earlier in the piece.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, am gratified to receive Senator Georges's assurance that the live sheep trade will not be terminated.
—Wait a minute! Don't take it too far.
—I have a Press release which says: `End to live sheep trade report'.
—How about reading the report and the statement?
—I accept your assurance but-
—But don't take it too far. Read the conclusions of the report.

—It certainly did cause a great deal of concern to the primary producers, particularly the wool producers of this country. I ask Senator Georges to put out his Press release on paper next time he feels inclined to issue a Press release. This industry is terribly important to all wool producers of Australia. The industry produces $208m. This is a way in which the producers can use their sheep which are no longer able to produce the sort of wool that is required for Australian export. Australian primary producers produce 40 per cent of our overseas exports and are facing a great deal of hardship at the moment. Of course, Australian primary producers need all the help they can get to encourage export trade and the promotion of export dollars which can reduce our deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Georges's report stated that we should be seeking refrigerated mutton sales in the Middle East. Whilst I agree with him that we should be not only seeking the sales in the Middle East but also promoting primary industry sales all over the world, the facts remain that the market forces state that people in the Middle East want live sheep. That is what they are prepared to buy and that is the only way we can meet the demands of the market. I commend the report. It contained a lot of very worthwhile recommendations. I have been talking to the rural industry people and to the national farmers and they commend the report as being very responsible. It is just unfortunate that the headline did come out of the statement Senator Georges made. I think everyone in the Senate at some time has been in a similar position as that which Senator Georges was in when he made a statement on the run and it was interpreted entirely differently.

One of the recommendations in the report is that the waterside workers be trained. I wonder whether it would be a worthwhile retirement career for Senator Georges when his term ends after three years. He might take up that proposal with his trade union connections and train waterside workers in the handling of live sheep exports. He could perhaps do that after the three or six years in which he has learnt animal husbandry as he has travelled around Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to remind the Senate that the report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, which examined the export of live sheep from Australia, acknowledged that any short term cessation of or disruption to the trade to the Middle East would cause considerable dislocation in both Australia and the Middle East. Consequently, I was pleased that the Committee agreed that the trade would continue for some years. Most people would agree that many problems which are still associated with the welfare of animals really need to be addressed. The export of live sheep has become a very important component of our wool and sheep industry and has made a significant contribution to the Australian economy over the last decade. I think the Committee recognised this when it said that animal welfare issues could not be divorced from economic considerations.

SPEECH.PARA: The live sheep export industry is very important to my State of Tasmania. So the unfortunate suggestion which resulted from media interpretation did cause many rural producers to run into some sort of panic, and rightly so. The rural industry, not only in Tasmania but also throughout Australia, is in a very depressed state at present, having to contend with numerous external forces which are virtually beyond its control. These include the dumping of surplus primary products on world markets at heavily discounted prices by the European Economic Community; the massive subsidies which are paid to European primary producers, which have enabled them to capture some of our traditional markets; the downturn in the consumption of red meat; and the rising farm costs which are the direct result of increasing government charges, taxes and tariffs. Any further attempt to destroy the viability of our rural industries, therefore, will be vigorously attacked, certainly by the farming sector.

According to report, the gross value of the live sheep export trade is about $217m a year. Without a doubt, this is a significant contribution to Australia's export earnings. Furthermore, the export of six million to seven million sheep has helped to raise sheep prices and has greatly increased productivity. The 1983 report by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics suggests that the average price, for example, received by farmers per sheep may have risen by as much as 20 per cent as a result of the live sheep export trade. As a consequence of the need for a considerable increase in the number of breeding ewes as a percentage of total sheep numbers, the live sheep export trade has contributed to an overall increase in the number of animals born each year and there has been an obvious shift from wool production to meat production. The value of the live sheep export trade can be seen not only in terms of earnings for the rural producers. The benefits from income received flow through to other sectors of the economy, particularly people who supply the producers and who depend on their custom.

In spite of the growth in the trade over the last few years there has been a visible downturn in profitability, due mainly to increased competition and price cutting attempts by Middle East importers. The live sheep export trade, like most Australian industries, must become more competitive on overseas markets. This can be achieved only by improving the quality of the product. I feel confident that if the Committee's recommendations relating to animal welfare are carried out the product that eventually reaches the market in the Middle East will be able to withstand the competition which is now coming from meat from the EEC and New Zealand. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Mr Acting Deputy President-
—Senator Georges, I take it you are exercising the right of reply.

—Yes. The reason I do this is that the methods we now use in the Senate to table reports limit the ability of the person tabling the report and those who follow to engage in a careful debate, not a garbled debate, on very important subjects. I believe that the Standing Orders Committee ought to take a look at what has happened and try to allocate more time for the presentation of these reports which have taken so much time and investigation to produce. For that reason I am taking advantage of replying briefly to what has been said whereas I could have done that, perhaps, at a later stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is necessary to make it perfectly clear that the report of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare concludes that on animal welfare grounds there is sufficient evidence that the live sheep export trade should be stopped immediately. Those grounds will persist and the industry should very carefully look at the fact that the pressures that have been applied in the past will not go away. Any major disaster at sea in this trade would lead to an increase of pressure to stop the trade, with more justification, perhaps, than there has been in the past. Some comments I made-incidentally, I say to Senator Boswell that I did not make those comments on the run-were reported in the Press. The best report of those comments came not in the Australian which contained a misreport, possibly not by the reporter himself but by the sub-editor who threw a very large subject into about three or four paragraphs, but from the Daily Commercial News which is a valuable journal to commerce, especially rural commerce. It contained the most balanced report of what happened.

I used terms such as the trade being fragile. I also said that on the basis of my experience the nature of the trade was changing. It is fairly obvious that Senator Boswell and Senator Brownhill are not aware of the changing nature of the trade. Perhaps they will not be aware, until they fully read the report, of who controls the trade, who can make the decisions that could alter the trade and who can, perhaps, make the decisions that could bring the trade to an end no matter what we want. There is a changing nature to the requirements of the Middle East towards younger sheep and the dependence of the wool industry upon this export trade might be, to use the word again, tenuous.

We said in the report that certain aspects of this trade ought to be carefully examined. The industry, if it fails to do so, does so at its own peril. For instance, on religious grounds-how important are these religious grounds is indicated by the fact that Iran was so quickly able to bring the live sheep trade to an end-we received evidence from the Federation of Islamic councils in Australia. It is responsible for the supervision of the slaughter of sheep in Australia for the Middle East. It receives a benefit from that. From its point of view it would be better if all the sheep were slaughtered in Australia. It is its view, on religious grounds, that the treatment of sheep and the way they are handled is not acceptable on animal welfare grounds. The Federation may have a vested interest in that it receives a return for every sheep slaughtered in Australia. I think the figure given to us was that the benefit to it for all sheep slaughtered in Australia for one year is $400,000. It is quite possible that it believes that to have more sheep slaughtered in Australia rather than transported live overseas would be to its benefit. It would be. There is no doubt that the Federation could bring influence to change religious attitudes overseas. Those attitudes are changing. Therefore, we should look very carefully at this industry and at the suggestion of the Committee. The Committee recommends on animal welfare grounds that the live sheep trade be phased out and substituted by refrigerated trade. If we look at this recommendation, not on animal welfare grounds but on economic grounds, we see that it is in the best interests of industry. It could diversify refrigerated trade away from the volatile Middle East.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they do not want it.

—One thing we can be certain of is that those who control the industry in the Middle East will not want it because they own the ships, by and large, but when the problems, such as drought, in Africa and in other countries that surround the Middle east start to disappear the greatest volume of live sheep supplied to the Middle East will come from those countries. It is quite possible that unless we anticipate this the trade could cease, not on animal welfare grounds but on economic grounds. I am saying to those who represent the rural industry that they should read the full report. They should read the recommendations on the basis that they are sound and responsible. Had they been made on purely animal welfare grounds we could have said: `The trade should stop. You sort it out'. We took the responsible course of going through the matter. We understood that trade was likely for a number of years in spite of whatever happened. We then looked at how best we could protect the interests of animals. I repeat, I hope that the comments made by the President of the National Farmers Federation were made from the hip. If I correctly recall the gentleman's attitude on other issues, he is inclined to fire from the hip. He has a sort of hip reaction to all politicians, particularly National Party politicians and, especially Mr Sinclair. Honourable senators should look at his comments.
—He gave Bob a few serves today.

—He has possibly given Bob a few serves. He gave me a serve in a letter which I have here. I put it to one side and did not answer it angrily. Today I took the opportunity of trying to correct him. The National Farmers Federation and the Animal Welfare Committee will be in close communication over the next two or three years when we come to investigate animal husbandry practices and examine intensive farming practices. It will be necessary to have the NFF's full co-operation and understanding and I am sure that we will get it.
